Award.AwardTitle: Ultrasensitivity in the Absence of Allostery for Multisite Chemical Reaction Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Multistite proteins have frequently been studied for their ability to produce all-or-none (ultrasensitive) responses to given stimuli. A widely made assumption is that of allostery, or the ability of one protein site to affect another through structural interactions. In recently published work by the PI and colleagues, it was shown that if more phosphorylation sites are present than are necessary for protein activation, a protein can produce ultrasensitive responses in the absence of allostery. In this project, the PI and graduate student will construct and analyze different input/output chemical reaction networks that are ultrasensitive (or bistable) as well as robust to stochastic noise and parameter changes. They will focus on nonsequential multisite networks in which ultrasensitivity or bistability arises naturally through network properties rather than through possibly restrictive conditions on parameter values (which are usually justified by allosteric properties). They will pursue specific applications beyond protein phosphorylation, such as DNA transcription regulation through packaging and histone modifications, signal transduction in clusters of membrane receptors, and gene expression regulation through binding of multiple identical transcription factors.

Cells are often faced with what one could describe as a decision to make: should it grow and divide in response to a given stimulus? Should it differentiate into a heart cell or a liver cell? Understanding the roots of cellular decision-making is a key problem in biology: for instance, a cell that divides too easily in response to a stimulus can - and often does - turn cancerous. In this proposal, the PI and student will seek to understand some of the basic mechanisms that cells likely use to produce such all-or-none behaviors. They will pursue an alternative to the so-called allosteric mechanism, which was first developed in work by Monod and others in 1965. While that elegant mechanism is rightly well known and widely cited, there may be many analogous biological systems where this property is not satisfied and which may have been overlooked. Recent work by the PI and colleagues provides an example of decision systems which are similar to allosteric systems but do not require that property. They will apply this principle to several specific systems of importance in molecular biology such as gene regulation and cell communication. They will also study the mathematical properties of these new systems and seek to collaborate with experimental biologists to determine to what extent these theoretical mechanisms represent actual biological functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multisite protein modification is a common form of regulation used by many biological organisms. It consists of the covalent attachment of residues or the binding of ligands, and it is known to change the functional activity of the protein. Multisite modification is essential for the control of cell division, the communication between cells, the transport of oxygen in the blood, and many other systems at the molecular level. An important role for such modifications is to create all-or-none, or ultrasensitive, responses to input stimuli.

During the course of this grant PI Enciso, along with several students and collaborators, searched for new design principles to conceptualize multisite modifications, working closely with experimental biologists to ensure that the mathematical work is relevant and consistent with observations. For example, we established a new modeling framework that allows for efficient, practical mathematical descriptions of multisite proteins, and applied it in the context of cell cycle regulation.  We discovered the role that a protein scaffold (such as a protein-binding membrane) can have in shaping the dynamics of a multisite protein.  We systematically studied how varying parameters for each site can affect the all-or-none nature of the system.  

Many of these results could not be obtained without the use of careful mathematical analysis. For instance, it is not obvious that binding to a scaffold can make a multisite protein a better biological switch, or why adding more sites to a multisite protein beyond the number needed for its activation can make it more ultrasensitive. Yet these results are consistently true over large values of parameters and likely applicable to many biological examples.  It is a strength of the mathematical analysis that the same model can be used over and over in different biological systems, as long as the model’s general assumptions are satisfied.  

One of the most successful mathematical models in biology is the work by Monod, Wyman, and Changeux, who in the 1960s described multisite proteins using the concept of allostery. This work is now thought to be the key to understand many problems such as the efficient transport of oxygen by hemoglobin. Our work stepped beyond this model, finding different sets of assumptions that can lead to similar conclusions.  We explored in particular that sites that are independent of each other (and therefore not allosteric) can also give rise to ultrasensitive responses. We believe that the results of this grant will be useful in situations where allostery may not hold, such as DNA packaging through multisite histone modification or multisite ligand binding.  

Regarding the broader impacts of this work, the PI has helped to create and expand on the Math CEO outreach project, a weekly activity for students of Lathrop and Villa Middle Schools in the predominantly Hispanic city of Santa Ana.  Middle school students come to UC Irvine to carry out extracurricular mathematics activities that will highlight STEM careers and motivate the students to continue to study after high school.  Regular meetings with parents of the students are also organized in Spanish, to stress the value of a college education and help guide them in this path.
